entry.title: The Raising of Lazarus (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Rembrandt liked the Jan Lievens painting The Raising of Lazarus (pictured) so much that he acquired it for himself?

entry.title: Luci van Org (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the singer Luci van Org followed up her mainstream success from the 1990s by starting a "Latin–disco–pop–country crossover" band?

entry.title: Daikoku Seamount (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a pond of liquid sulfur was discovered at the summit crater of the Daikoku Seamount in 2006 in the Northern Mariana Islands?

entry.title: John McClaughry (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that before John McClaughry was elected to the Vermont House of Representatives, he traveled about 5,000 miles (8,000 km) in boxcars as a hobo?

entry.title: Let's Dance (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that David Bowie's song "Let's Dance" began as a folk song?

entry.title: Glimmer (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the rebooted design of Glimmer from She-Ra was partly inspired by the showrunner's love of Dungeons & Dragons?

entry.title: Evans Bay Patent Slip (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Evans Bay Patent Slip was built in 1871 using hundreds of tons of machinery that had sat on a beach for five years?

entry.title: a French chair umpire (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the "Barry White of tennis" is a French chair umpire?
